column1: Most adults (and all children) receive general anesthesia.
Depending on what needs to be done, the surgeon will: - Clean out any infection or dead tissue on the eardrum or in the middle ear.

- Remove, replace, or repair one or more of the three little bones in the middle ear (called ossuculoplasty) - Repair smaller holes in the eardrum by placing either gel or a special paper over the eardrum (called myringoplasty).
The surgeon will use an operating microscope to view and repair the eardrum or the small bones.

Causes of holes or openings in the eardrum include: - A bad ear infection - Sticking something inside the ear canal - Surgery to place ear tubes - Trauma If the eardrum has a fairly small hole, myringoplasty may work to close it.
Most of the time, your doctor will wait at least 6 weeks after the eardrum developed a hole before suggesting surgery.

Tympanoplasty may be done if: - The eardrum has a larger hole or opening - There is a chronic infection in the ear, and antibiotics do not help - There is a buildup of extra tissue around or behind the eardrum These same problems can also harm the very small bones (ossicles) that are right behind the eardrum.
If this happens, your surgeon may perform an ossiculoplasty.

Risks for any surgery are: - Bleeding - Infection - Problems breathing - Reactions to medications Other risks include: - Damage to the facial nerve or nerve controlling the sense of taste - Damage to the small bones in the middle ear, causing hearing loss - Dizziness or vertigo - Incomplete healing of the hole in the eardrum - Worsening of hearing, or, in rare cases, complete loss of hearing
- Give your child a small sip of water with any drugs your doctor instructed your child to take.
- The doctor will make sure your child is healthy enough for surgery.
This means your child has no signs of illness or infection.
On the day of the surgery (for adults): - Take only a small sip of water with any drugs your doctor has prescribed.
In most cases, the procedure relieves pain and infection symptoms completely.
